title: Worryingly disappointed
body: I phoned dead on 8am for an appointment for my 16 year old daughter on Monday and eventually got through after a 20 minute wait. I was told she would have a phone call. At 5pm I called again as there had been no callback. Yes, she was still on the list! 2 days later, still no call so i phoned for a third time as my daughter has severe anxiety and depression and i am worried about her. I was told that yet again she would be put on the list for a duty doctor to call and still no callback. This is appalling especially when teenagers are hurting themselves or worse during this awful time. I am so angry 😡 and I am still worried about my daughter's mental health, especially as she is returning to college next week.

author: pyxisfr34
title: CMHT waiting times putting health at serious risk.
body:
I was referred to the CMHT by the crisis team last July (2020) following a suicide attempt which left me in a coma. The crisis team refused to allow me to see one of their psychiatrist and stated I would have to wait to see the CMHT. Due to the wait (I was advised it would be 12 weeks), I had to go private which put me into debt.  
In January of this year I ended up in hospital due to Lithium Toxicity, I had put off my scheduled appointment with my private psychiatrist as I could not afford it, however having access to a psychiatrist would have prevented my hospital admission. I saw RRLP in hospital who were excellent, they advised they would bump my referral to the CMHT up to urgent. My private psychiatrist had advised both myself and RRLP that he felt I needed the CMHT as he felt his support was not enough for someone in my circumstances. I was therefore discharged having been taken off Lithium and not put on another mood stabiliser.  
Two weeks later I received my appointment date with the CMHT, - 9 months after I had been originally referred and 3 months after my referral had been made urgent. I was therefore being left unmedicated for 3 months, as I knew this would put my mental health and my employment at serious risk I had to again see a private psychiatrist. I had to borrow money in order to do this, putting myself further into debt. I have recently received a letter putting my appointment further back a further week.  
Leaving someone with Bipolar 9 months to see a psychiatrist after a serious suicide is absolutely appalling.

author: Ellhj83
title: I felt my vaccinator didn't believe me
body:
All the staff couldn't have been more pleasant and helpful except my vaccinator. She told me the appointments were for registered carers only and where was my shielding letter? (Why would I have a shielding letter, I'm a carer).  
I said I was a carer and have my carer's ID card but she didn't want to see it. She said the booking site had to be closed down because of false claimers. I said I knew but I was a carer. I felt she was accusing me I was not carer.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Fantastic staff
body:
After having nasty accident in garden resulting in damage to face which needed treatment. Seen by emergency within one hour.
From arrival and seen with great concern by receptionist to beeing treated by nurse with great care and follow up I could not ask for more, 
Thank you all so very much in these difficult times, sorry I caused you more work

author: Patiently Deaf
title: Problem booking blood test requested by GP when profoundly deaf
body:
1 am 65 years old, profoundly deaf and my wife who was hearing died in November 2020. I relied on her for those occasions when phone calls are received. I now live on my own.  
In January 2021 I attended an annual health review requested by my GP. I was given a form for several blood tests to be carried out. Due to Covid restrictions appointments have to be booked by phone or on line in advance. As I am deaf the phone option is not available especially bearing in mind the phenomenally long call waiting times. Asking someone not close to me to phone was not an option. That should have been OK as there is an option to book on line. However on going to the site and submitting the request it turned out the ONLY option available was to wait up to two days to receive a CALLBACK on my phone. If it was not answered promptly I would lose the option to receive whatever the call back was arranging and will have to PHONE in the usual way. There is no alternative way provided for a deaf person alone to arrange the booking appointment.  
No option for email or text is provided. I have complained to PALS NHS Lewisham and Greenwich area and have been contacted in March by them informing me that the phlebotomy department has been sent my email address and hopefully will contact me soon (I am writing this in March and am still awaiting a reply).  
Earlier today while my mobile was in another room at home I receive a phone call from a number a recognize as QE2 Hospital Woolwich. From experience dealing with it while my wife was dying I know it's one of those "press number X for whatever you require" contact numbers this is no good to me of course.  
I had no alternative but to go back to my GP reception in person and tell them it was impossible for a deaf person to book a phlebotomy appointment by themselves.  
The receptionist understood my plight and the impossible situation I was in. She phoned the number for booking an appointment. After a few minutes she was told that she was number 44 in the queue. Obviously, the receptionist like a previous person I asked to help couldn't wait that long as other people were awaiting her attention. She finally gave me an appointment at the Gallions Health Centre itself, for the earliest available there on 15th March virtually another two weeks away. Hopefully I don't have any blood conditions that will require immediate attention.  
As a profoundly deaf person now on my own, I am finding this a common problem. All too often no alternative to arranging things by phone is provided. Today's technology emails and text should be routine. When my wife died I informed my Health Centre to make a note on my records to contact me by text when they want me to arrange something with them. As I would miss requests to attend for example flu vaccinations normally via landline phone which I no longer use.

links.id: a way for deaf people to make bookings

author: heva35
title: Brilliant care in difficult times
body: 8 weeks ago I under went a hysterectomy at Whiston Hospital. It was a very last minute offer of a date during crazy pandemic times. They still managed a brilliant pre op 'gyn school' with me which helped with fears and anxieties I had. Once in for my surgery the staff were amazing and completely reassuring with any concerns or questions. Not having family around was hard going and the catering, HCA and support staff certainly helped with just little bits of chit chat when around the wards, its these little things that really lifted spirits when you don't have visitors. The nurses were clearly stretched and and the hospital was starting to feel the pressures of COVID but their care never faulted. I really think their work on pre-op care, pre-load drinks, physio guidance, diet advice and general positive wellbeing support before, during and after care has made my recovery speedy and problem free.

readBy.name: St Helens and Knowsley Hospitals NHS Trust

author: Juliemariet
title: Dermatology appointment not with dermatologist
body:
I was referred to East Surrey dermatology department for a changing mole on my side (my GP thought it was a pyogenic granuloma, but could not be 100% certain).  
East Surrey offered for me to use the MySkinDoctor app, which I did, as I thought this would be the better option during these times. The response was quick - they said they could also not make a certain diagnosis from the photos and would see me in clinic, where the lesion would be examined with a dermatoscope and would possibly be removed during the appointment.  
I arrived at East Surrey Outpatients and went in for my appointment, only to be "blindsided" by the fact that my appointment was not with a dermatologist, but a general surgeon. They were unable to answer any of my questions and did not examine the lesion at all - they said they had just been instructed by dermatology to remove it. I was shocked by this, but felt I had no choice but to proceed and have the mole removed (whether it was actually necessary or not).

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: MMccord
title: Ward 32 Royal Alexandra hospital
body:
I was admitted to ward 32 for surgery on an afternoon list and an overnight stay. On my arrival to the ward I was met by a friendly face who showed me to my allocated bed space and shown the bathroom, locker space and told to make myself at home.  
I was cared for by Staff nurses called Karen on both a day and night shift ( just to keep it simple for me I'm sure) Diana my HCSW overnight was kind, thoughtful and nothing was too much of an effort. I needed assistance several times overnight and not once was I made to feel like a nuisance (even though I felt like one!) Charge Nurse Lynn cared for me on day 2 and even carried my bag down to the car so I didn't need to carry it.  
I had a chat with ward Sister Nikki and conveyed my thanks . I am aware that even though the NHS has had a very hard year Nikki and team are still providing an excellent standard of nursing care.  
I have never before felt compelled to use such a platform but I wanted to state publicly what a great team work on Ward 32.

title: Pain Clinic - not much use
body:
I was referred to the Pain Clinic more than 2 years ago (very bad hip pain.)  A few visits, a long wait between - and treatment offered did little or nothing to help - eg. use of Tens machine, steroid injection to the hip, etc.  Before 1st lockdown, another steroid injecton discussed and agreed.  Since then, all I have heard about it was a call just before Christmas to see if I still wanted it.  I said yes, although the latest x-rays led my GP to suggest there was no way to get a needle into the hip joint!  If I have waited a year for that jab, how long will I have to wait for a hip replacement??

Being treated privately is very expensive, of course - but it looks like my only sensible option.  I wonder how many others of my age (71) or more who are also waiting but couldn't afford to go private??

X-ray department has been very good when my GP wanted another x-ray - only a short wait for an appointment and GP received x-rays/report very quickly.  But the Pain Clinic has been VERY slow - while my pain has doubled (at least) since my last visit (about February 2020),

author: IOWTOMMY
title: my substace misuse struggle
body: after struggling for over 25 years with drugs and alcohol I came into recovery for the 3rd time, This time was different I wanted it I was a broken man inclusion opened their arms and grabbed me I felt part of a family and started my recovery journey doing groups and regular 1-1 recovery sessions since then I have been clean and sober to date 2 years 5 months. inclusion IOW will always have a place in my heart alongside the lovely team and service users.

author: The Blade
title: Emergency stay in MEAU
body:
Everything from admission to discharge was conducted in a very professional manner with full explanations given in respect of all procedures.Returned for a colonoscopy a later date and was again treated in a most attentive manner by all the staff.  
My treatment throughout was exemplary.

author: sagittath34
title: My mums hospital stay.
body:
My mum was admitted to Monklands hospital on hogmanay 2020 with low oxygen and high heart rate.  
Mum was looked after in ward 17, the staff were fantastic. My mum was then moved to ward 2 high dependency for 1 night then taken to ward 26 intensive care, where she was put on a ventilator. Mum had very low oxygen levels due to having Corona virus back in November 2020, so scarring to her lungs, long covid.  
Mum was on the ventilator for 9 days and was moved to differant areas including Theatre 3 which was being used for patients who didn't have covid as an intensive care because of the high number of cases of covid. The full time she was in a coma (and out) the staff were exceptional with calling and giving me lots of reassurance to my mums care.  
My mum, once off the ventilator was moved back to high dependency ward 18 and again all staff went above and beyond in keeping me informed. Mum finished her stay back were she started in ward 17 with all the familiar faces she had seen before. The nurses are absolutely outstanding and deserve all the credit for getting my mum back to full health.  
Big massive thank you from us all 👏👏👏🌈

readBy.name: Office of John Mason, MSP for Glasgow Shettleston

title: Poor and unhelpful customer service.
body:
When I need to call to arrange an Doctor or nurse appointment, first at all they never have an appointment available, and I've been calling as soon the line is open. Is a nightmare to get one. You have  to keep calling several weeks untill you can get one. 

My personal description of their customer service:
Rude discourteous behavier, long waits in line, lack of manners, lack of empathy, Non-caring, disrespectful attitudes during the call, employees dealing with consultations and phone booking appointments doesn't care about anything, they just asnwer they way they want without any ethics and customer values. I don't really recommend this place.

title: Great, efficient practice
body: As a busy keyworker in this pandemic, I really appreciate how efficient they have been, allowing me to place my questions via econsult with a personalised text from a doctor informing me of either my next steps or my results.  On top of it all, I have to say I am so grateful for the personalised condolences letter I received last April following my father's death.  It was really thoughtful.  I have always found the reception really polite and efficient

author: thubanbm83
title: Virtual Visiting Service
body:
My Dad has been in and out of hospital since November 2020 and the Virtual Visiting Service has been invaluable to us as a family. 2 of his daughters live outside the Southern Trust and this service would be great to have even if Covid was not an issue. To be able to see daddy on the screen is just such a blessing. The staff who man the phones are always very helpful.
Many thanks

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Fantastic treatment thank You
body:
I was treated for a dog bite. Every member of staff was kind helpful and friendly and looked after me really well.
They gave me the medicines I needed cleaned the wound and x rayed and referred me to plastics at the JR. 
The staff here in Witney MIU are wonderful and really made me feel very cared for especially during such a difficult time. I was treated really well and really quickly. Thank you so much

title: Vaccine rollout
body: I had my covid vaccine at the surgery and I have to say how well organised the whole experience was. The staff were super organised and the volunteers were so happy & friendly. Well done to all!

title: Radiology/ultrasound department was superb
body: Been here twice for scans in last 6 months and was both nervous and embarrassed about a testes scan but both operatives were superb made me feel at ease and could sense my anxiousness well done absolute credit to the Hospital and NHS only sorry I didn’t take both guys names

title: Appalling rude and ignorant reception staff
body: I have always respected the doctors and staff at leatside where I was a patient for many years. However after many years of devotion  and respect I moved to Somerset. Their attitude changed all were rude aggressive and ignorant. They failed to tell me that I had been deregisteted and would not even answer a simple repeat prescription request. I find their appalling behaviour and rudeness insulting and disgusting. To treat a loyal patient of many years standing is despicable and very offensive

author: wearingyp89
title: My Experience
body:
I wanted to give you and your team some feedback on my recent visit to Northwick Park's A and E department and Surgical Assessment Unit.  
I was extremely impressed by the way all the staff took care of me during my visit. From the prompt attention I recieved for my acute hearing loss in A and E. The care and attention to detail of all who made decisions about my condition.  
I was subsequently seen on level four of the SAU by an excellent staff nurse and a superb ENT doctor called Jack. Elizabeth a very kindly caring lady made me an excellent cup of coffee and was extremely kind to me in every way possible.  
I left with a prescription greatly reassured and await further care.  
Thank you to all of your team who were with me on that Tuesday.  
With sincere grateful thanks.  
Yours sincerely,

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Molfq48
title: Lack of appropriate care and help
body:
I am a 65 year old woman. When I was a child I was both sexually abused and physically abused in Ireland. This was from two until I was about 12. I then married at 16 to get away from both the abuse, and the whole town who alienated me . I had a very lonely life. The man I married was another abuser. I was beaten regularly. I had two children but lost seven. We split when I was 21. In Ireland then there was no provision for a woman with two children. We were basically a mans possession. My husband took the two children put one in a orphanage and gave one to his brother.  
I moved to Britain. I suffered dreadfully with my mental health. I was diagnosed with Borderline Personally Disorder, Endogenous depression, and Post Traumatic Stress disorder. Never had any help from mental health authorities. Other than sending a psychiatric nurse. Who could not diagnose a cold. I attempted suicide too many times, unfortunately never successfully.  
I had my first stroke in my 30’s, I then had a heart attack, and a second mini stroke. When I got in my mid 40’s I needed help with physical things like washing, dressing, etc, This is when I got in contact with Trafford Adult Social Service. Since then my life has been a living hell. I am now terminally ill. Every time I contact them they treat me like rubbish. There tone is very aggressive, because of my stroke my memory is not great. I need 24 hour care. I get 32 a week. I asked for a little more help. I got a call, asking what I do with the 32 hours, I was trying to remember everything, I was told they don’t allow three quarters of an hour for washing, dressing, breakfast. I explained I can’t go any quicker and that when they access they send two carers, but they expect one carer to do it in the same time. I was then asked if I had filled in some chc form with my GP. I don’t even know what there on about. I was never dying before now. I am then told to ring my GP to chase up McMillan nurses. I can’t even get out of bed. They have no empathy in my last months. I am at the stage now, that I want to cancel all care. It just brings the end quicker. I need help not a jobs worth. Maybe then they might consider how they are treating people. But I am sure they will come out with their usual excuse “lessons to be learned”. But I can’t take anymore fighting for some help. I think my choice of cancelling everything , if nothing else gives me some peace.  
I would like to say thank you, to them, but to be honest, I can’t, from they one they never even took in to account there own social workers assessment of the care I needed. I have multiple co- morbidities , epilepsy, pherephial neuropathy, osteoporosis. COPD, emphysema, asthma, angina, heart disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, can’t walk, can’t open my front door, can’t get any shopping, can’t wash, can’t dress, can’t get any shopping delivered, who is going to open the door. Breathless just sitting, Maybe when they see what their actions do to people they might just think a little before they drive the next person to giving up.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: J50FD
title: Treated with professionalism and courtesy at A&E
body:
I had reason to attend A&E at NHSCT where I was treated with professionalism and courtesy from the Phone First service to my attendance at minor injuries.  
Nurses Ann and Orla, Dr Paula and pharmacist Rachel, their care and expertise was wholly evident. They made me proud of our health and social care service but particularly the NHSCT.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shirley66
title: My recent admission to hospital
body:
I arrived by ambulance to a&e friday 19 feb I couldnt of ask 4 better treatment from the word go  
I would like to thank all involved; ambulance crew, a&e staff, Respiratory hub, Ward 4a, Ward 9, Porters, Cleaners, Catering, Pharmacy.  
My stay was second to none appreciate everything  
I'm now at home recuperating being treated as a outpatient the care is impeccable.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: hekadc54
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Kindness at Urgent Care Centre
body:
My wife was attending Downe Hospital for her second cataract surgery which was 100% successful. I had gone out to feed a stray cat in the morning and fell on the frost breaking my glasses and cutting my eye.  
My wife was telling the nurse (Mary Frances) while at her cataract surgery about my fall and the cut to my eye, the nurse went out of her way to call me to tell me to come to reception and to go to Urgent Care Centre.  
A nurse met me at the door of the hospital. I would highly praise the nurse who contacted me for going above and beyond and for her kindness which was beyond reproach.  
I went to the Urgent Care Centre and the receptionist was excellent, I then saw a nurse who took my BP who asked me some questions. I then saw a lady doctor who put 3-4 stitches in my eyelid. I waited no more than 5 minutes to be seen and was out within 45 minutes to meet my wife following her surgery. I found this treatment to be unbelievable and my eye has 100% recovered.  
I would like to forward my thanks to Mary Frances, the lady doctor and staff at UCC for their treatment and kindness I received which was excellent. I was given tea and toast after my procedure and was also given a tetanus.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: GMB2021
title: Anxiety and Depression
body:
I had gone through multiple ordeals the previous years which include the breakdown of a relationship and on/off harassment which I would try to report to the police and they wouldn’t help. It affected my physical health as well as emotional health, which resulted in me losing weight, losing my hair and generally becoming unwell which resulted in having to go to hospital.  
I was diagnosed with depression in 2019 and I was put on anti-depressants. I felt so sad and like my life was spiralling out of control, I felt I didn’t have no control in my life and that I had lost who I was. I full of anger and hurt from what I had been through. I had had counselling on and off throughout the last few years but last year become a breaking point for me and I went back to Inclusion and started having counselling again last July.  
My counsellor was Ian. We would have counselling every week via telephone. He helped me to see what was positive in my life and the positivity in myself. He also suggested some great things to help which was writing my feelings down when I felt sad or angry and even watching videos to help with my emotions. Every couple of weeks, my anxiety scores would go up or go down, due to having a bad week here and there but Ian would help bring them back down. All I needed was someone to listen to me whether if I was crying or angry and Ian was there to listen. I had had counselling for roughly 7-8 months with Ian, it really benefitted me having it for as long as I did as it’s helped me to turn my life around now.  
I am much happier now, I have gained a little more weight, I eat more and I don’t feel as depressed like I used to. I still have down days here and there but Ian taught me that this is normal and that if I feel like I need to speak to someone again, I can ring Inclusion and ask for him. Thank you Ian and Inclusion service for your help and for helping turn my life around.

author: Mairiemeg
title: Dvt. Ultrasound and exanination
body: Rapid response from my GP.   Ultrasound the next day followed by a visit to dvt nurse, who took blood. I waited for the result.   Massive blood clot in my thigh.   Nurse explained condition and I was sent home with rivaroxaban.   Everyone so kind and dvt nurse Stephanie explained the procedure.   I understood perfectly and am very grateful to her for a clear explanation.   Very grateful to my GP who phoned to ask the result of my visit.

author: Monklands Endoscopy Service
title: Experience Endoscopy Unit
body: I was incredibly nervous and worried about attending . The team were fantastic in the Endoscopy unit and in theatre . Particular thanks to Miss Sharma who explained everything and appreciated my anxiety . Working in the NHS myself experiencing NHS services from the other side made me feel so vulnerable and worried I cannot thank the team involved enough .

author: skygn89
title: Closer to home.
body:
I was going to Derriford for a few years before maintaining my treatment at Torrington.  
It is very beneficial for me to have my treatment in my local area, due to having other health problems including diabetes. I can’t go too far without having to check my sugars and act accordingly.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: lyrarx44
title: Home physiotherapist treatment
body:
Due to cov19 my classes stopped at Wishaw hospital Feb 2020. Home therapist Becca was sent out in September 2020. Initially I had lost all confidence in my walking with above knee prothesis leg. This girl came to me and first day had restored my confidence by 80%, given exercises to strengthen upper body and stump. Within 4 sessions walking confidently indoors by myself.  
Due to dangerous step outside flat not able to go out in crutches. She organised and provided equipment to improve independence in home. NHS wheelchair (I had bought my own one on ebay ) which was not comfortable and developed faults after 11 months. Provided stool for in kitchen so I could prepare my food out of wheelchair. A gripper stick to stop me bending over. A device to grip onto going in and out of bed to safe me throwing myself on bed. These 3 items gave me so much more independence and made life bearable. Finally I got a safe step and today taught how to get out using crutches.  
It was like winning the lottery being imprisoned in my flat for 18mths. I cannot thank Becca and services enough for giving me this freedom and lifting my depression and frustrations. Thank you a million times just awesome work everyone does to give me back my life.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: microscopiumyf59
title: Thank you
body:
Everything went great  
Thank you for this service

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: paperchase
title: Ovarian cancer
body:
I cannot fault all the nurses, doctors, consultants, health assistants and more that have helped me during my treatment. They have been happy to explain diagnosis and listen to any problems with treatment.  
I think that what has made the biggest difference is that they are genuinely interested in your well being and follow up your care.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust
Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

author: Caddie
title: Convenient for me
body:
I use the day treatment units have my blood transfusion and I am very grateful to have such a well-run and caring unit in which to have my treatment. All of the nurses are very kind and caring towards me which makes it a pleasure for me to sit and enjoy being there passing the time talking to them and my fellow patients whenever I am being attended to it is done with care and consideration making it obvious that their patients’ needs are always put first.  
The room used is always spotlessly clean by the staff at the hospital and the room temperature is kept at a comfortable level in the chairs that we sitting very comfortable.  
My only thought for improvement would be that at the moment the windows have been covered with a privacy film to give us privacy but the ones used also prevent us being able to look out, it would have been nice if the type of film that does let us look out had been used. The only other thought would be for the lighting while it is adequate to relax in it seems to me that the nurses could do with more light when they are attending to us.  
The unit is very convenient for patients like me to use so I am very grateful for its existence and hope that it may continue in the future.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Rosyface
title: Refusal to provide ADHD testing
body:
We have been pursuing a referral for diagnosis for adult ADHD for my husband for some time now, and it keeps being declined by the mental health team with no reasons being provided to us.  
the last referral was sent off a few weeks ago, including a copy of a completed DIVA diagnostic questionnaire that is in use in NHS Scotland that I went through with my husband, that highly suggests he has ADHD. His GP agreed to send off the referral and was very sympathetic, but for some reason the mental health team is refusing to see him. These refusals are contributing to other issues, such as depression, which is also very common in undiagnosed ADHD patients.  
He was initially referred around 3 years or so ago to the Dr at Woodlands to discuss depression and ADHD, which as I detailed in my email to the GP, did not go very well as he struggles to advocate for himself in high pressure scenarios and masks his ADHD symptoms in these situations in an attempt to focus on the situation at hand and answer the questions. This led to the Dr deciding without completing any diagnostic questionnaires that he did not have ADHD. I went with him to the recall appointment a few weeks later and asked specifically about ADHD and the Dr was incredibly rude and dismissive towards me and refused to discuss it. We were unhappy with this experience as the Dr acted pretty horribly but unsure what to do next.  
My husband's symptoms are still present and he struggles with everyday life as a result, and his GP made the referral. We spoke to the GP surgery today as we had heard nothing back, who gave us another number for the FVRH psychiatry team to chase the referral. They were confused why it hadn’t been referred to them and couldn’t give us any other information other than the name of someone who had been knocking back the referrals and they didn’t know why, and were confused about why he was instead referred to Woodlands. We are being given the run-around and can’t get in touch with anyone at Woodlands to actually discuss this as their phone is just ringing out.  
This refusal to provide him with any care is abhorrent and is forcing us to have to save money for however long it takes to pay for private diagnosis (we can't afford this), and then we have to hope that shared care is available, which it generally is not. I cannot afford to be saving upwards of £1000 simply because the NHS is failing him. It's disgusting.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Professional and caring
body: I was naturally anxious when I was advised to have a partial knee replacement, but my concerns were soon put to rest on entering the hospital. All the staff both clinical and non-clinical were incredibly professional, caring and very approachable and soon put my mind to rest. I would like to thank them all for their hard work in these difficult times and will certainly recommend the hospital to anyone needing similar surgery. Thank you all, you are wonderful... I know you can't say that about yourselves but I certainly can; and I know many others say the same. Thank you once again.

author: Simpysimp
title: Pulled Elbow
body: My son was treated at the Victoria Hospital Kirkcaldy for a “Pulled Elbow”. He was seen and treated within an hour by a friendly and professional ENP Kirstie. Thank you so much.

author: OneandonlyMrsT
title: Well organised Covid Vaccine
body:
I attended this morning for my covid vaccine. I was very happy to have the vaccine but felt nervous attending the surgery. I had nothing to be nervous about! The vaccination clinic was organised so well. Staff ensured that Safe distancing was observed and it ran very smoothly. Despite how busy it was I waited less than 10 minutes for the jab and all the staff were friendly and professional. Thank you so much to the Staff at The Healthcare Surgery for making the experience feel safe, they work extremely hard at all times for their patients but have excelled themselves during the pandemic.  
No improvements needed.

title: It is hard to book appointments but also hard to…
body: All staff have been very nice and professional at all times.   I was unable to book an appointment to see a GP via telephone.,The phone just makes an engaged sound.   The telephone service is not good.  Patients cannot get through.  It is not acceptable to have to continuously keep calling.  Other GPS telephone systems tell you what position that you are waiting to be answered in.  Although, this can be a wait, at least you have an idea of what wait you have.  I had to actually go in the GP to book appointment because I could not get through on the telephone.  Then I could not get through to cancel and appointment.  Which seems very sad because someone else could of had my appointment who needed it.  All because the telephone system is rubbish.  GP surgery inside is pleasant enough.   And I was able to get 2 GP appointments quite fast as I needed them quick.  So they are some positive thing.  It’s a shame the telephone system lets the whole place down.  The internet site needs sorting out as not working.  Maybe this could be an easy way to cancel appointments if needed.

author: Nelli2018
title: Fibromyalgia
body: I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia 3 years ago. The doctors have done their best to help me with medication but I was losing a lot of time off work. Before I was diagnosed I worked 7 days a week and was always busy doing something and helping others. But my life had changed so much in the 3 years since I was diagnosed. All I was doing was sleeping and working, only managing to work monday till friday and it was a struggle. Then I was referred to an Occupational Therapist on October 2020. What a diffrence to my life that has made. Even just havin someone to talk to and beleive in your pain, made a big difference. I have now got a diffrent outlook on life and being able to manage my pain a bit better. I still have appointments with my OT every week and she is great at helping me manage my pain and listening to me. I was off work for 12 weeks and she organised a return to work on shorter hours and gradually building it back up to 5 days. This would never have happened if I didn't have my OT as I have worked in my job for 37 years and I am the 1st person to work these hours through an OT. Without her I would be in a much darker place and In a lot more pain and just getting by with my life. She has made a massive difference to my life now and I am so grateful that she's there for me and still is.

author: Angry asthmatic
title: Shocking receptionist
body:
I said excuse me to receptionist had been up 2 times she didn’t even lift her head and acknowledge me, casualty wasn’t really that busy been here hours after arriving in ambulance a bit of manners would have been appreciated  
Utter disgust at their behaviour I will be taking this further

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: FeedbackMarch
title: Cancelling Surgery Last Minute
body: My partner's mother has been crippled most of 3 years, she finally gets her operation date which means soon she can finally hold and care for her new grandchild to help me through this pandemic whilst my partner works away amongst other normal things like sleep and walk properly without pain. You cancelled on her less than 24 hours before she was due to go in after she had her covid test, isolated and got her husband to set up the bedroom furniture downstairs for her. I feel gutted for her but that is not fair someone higher up has decided her operation and bed can be given when she has already waited this long. Less than 24 hour notice for a life changing operation is not care or putting the patient first! This not only impacts on her life, her husband, her job, her 4 children and her 5 grandchildren and my life as a new single parent in a pandemic.

author: listen65
title: Communication for patients and relatives
body:
Following an unplanned operation, my father was transferred to Ward 29 after contracting Covid-19 from Ward 11. He later passed away in hospital from Sepsis. The communication strategy was non existent. They had no mechanism in place to keep us relatives informed about how our loved ones were doing. Instead I was having to constantly phone - so much effort and energy was expended in just trying to get through on the phone. Either the phone was unanswered or it was engaged.  
I made a complaint. I was assured they are working on improving communication which I didn't really beleive because how is it possible that so many months on from the start of the pandemic a communications strategy is not in place for relatives of patients? With all the great minds working in the NHS no one thought about putting in place alternative communication structures to ensure relatives are adequately updated especially at a time when visiting is not allowed?.  
I appreciate the work load has increased exponentially but it is not beyond their gift to implement an effective communication strategy not only for the well being of patients but also relatives.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: RobynG
title: Gender bias at GP Practice
body:
I am a 23 year old female and I have been seeing this gp for the past three years, most of what I have been going to the gp for in this time has been mental issues including depression and anxiety. I noticed symptoms of autism and adhd between 2019 and 2020. the symptoms have been there since I was a child but due to family issues I was unable to start the process until I was in my 20s. When I went to my gp about this I was told (even though I had proof of the autism test online and adhd test online) that autism is not seen in females and was dismissed until september 2020 when I phoned again to get an assessment.  
I have also had problems being put on the right medication. I am on antidepressants and have now been on 3 different ones with all results showing that they are not working. I have had to fight each time and unless I have had a male with me nothing has been changed. the most recent was when my partner had to go with me to get my medication changed to no avail as I was told my mental issues are down to my weight (I am overweight but not morbidly and am working to lose weight for my own sake) and that if I lost weight I wouldn't be depressed or anxious. when in psychology I have brought up the fact that I think I might have autism and adhd I feel like that has been pushed to the side and all that psychology and psychiatry has focused on is childhood trauma from my mum dying in front of me and other issues with my dad.  
I feel like its a vicious cycle of telling my gp that my mental issues are here and not trauma related him saying that it's my weight and me getting annoyed at not being heard. I'm doing my HNC in applied science and one of my essays is on Neurodiversity so I'm not just a stupid little girl that doesn't know any better I have done the research for my own sake and being graded on my knowledge of this. I need him to listen instead of dismissing me even when the severity of my mental issues are on show ( I have self harm scars because that is the only way I knew how to deal with my issues). sorry for the long ramble but I am sick of being dismissed for being overweight and what genitals I have.

author: charliemc69
title: Pre-assessment Appointment
body:
I care for my Dad and took him to his pre-assessment appointment. We were called in on time and the staff nurse went through some of the questions. When he got to the medication section he asked Dad about the blood thinning drugs and Dad said that the cardiologist told him to stop them, March 2020. The staff nurse went back to the letter that was sent out following this appointment and it said to stop two of the medication but not both blood thinning drugs. The nurse starting to get 'cross' and said something similar to 'you shouldn't have stopped both of these, you could have a heart attack at any time' Both myself and Dad felt very humiliated as if it was our fault. Dad has never had his medication reviewed by his GP or the hospital.  
We needed to see an anaesthetist, so he was called, but due to his urgent schedule didn't arrive. We waited over 3 hours. However the rest of the staff in the Pre--Assessment department were really helpful and gave us something to eat and drink.  
  
[Very unhappy with 'Staff attitude']  
  
[Happy with 'Reception']

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Rosslyn
title: Cardiac Liaison Nurse
body: I have attended many appointments for my daughter who has congenital heart disease. There has been a fairly newly appointment Cardiac Liasion Nurse. Previously I have had to link with Cardiac Liasion Nurses in Glasgow as the role did not exist in NHS Lothian. I am delighted that this role now exists and is a brilliant support for families in Edinburgh.

author: LCon
title: Day appointment Day Intervention Ward
body:
I was scheduled for a biopsy last week in February 2021. I had reservations about my biopsy as I have been diagnosed with Lynch Syndrome, I discussed my concerns with a Staff Nurse who was duty that morning, I explained my concerns and wanted to discuss with the Dr before going ahead with biopsy. The Staff Nurse listened to my concerns and arranged a call to the Dr that would be performing my biopsy in Queen Margaret Hospital Dunfermline.  
The Staff Nurse relayed the advice from the Dr advising me the biopsy would be safe to go ahead with. All staff were supportive this day and all hadn't heard of Lynch Syndrome and I shared this information with all staff, student nurse Aimee, Staff Nurse Michelle, Staff Nurse Keren and Andy. All these staff in Day Intervention Ward were very supportive and professional during a very concerning time for me. I can't thank them enough and in particular Dr Rishi who took the time to discuss my situation with a specialist cancer colleague, and Dr Rishi decision to not go ahead with biopsy and his reasons why were very reassuring and I was relieved and also very impressed with Dr Rishi explanation of expediting my case forward.  
Its reassuring when Medical clinicians and Nursing Staff listen to patients particularly when its a diagnosis such as Lynch Syndrome is sometimes not known by them. I've have since heard an mri scan is being arranged as urgent. I am again very impressed and thankful to all staff with my ongoing care support pathway during a very difficult time for me.  
Many thanks everyone in our fantastic NHS Fife Teams.

author: Sick to my stomach
title: Stroke Victim
body:
A few years ago my partner was admitted by a 999 call to A& E for a suspected stroke around 6pm ish. He was left on a corridor still on the Gynae until the next morning. Nobody came to see him. The lights were switched out and was obviously forgotten about. He was finally admitted to ward the following morning where he had all the necessary obs. This happened for 10 days until they discharged him. There was no scans done nothing!  
It was obvious there had been a lack of oxygen to his brain. I went to collect him to find him wandering down the corridor confused and wobbling as though he was drunk. He didn't recognise me. He had a blank expression in his face. I said surely they haven't discharged you in this state. He said they had. It took me a while to get him to the car. Thinking he had discharged himself! I phoned the hospital to see if they had discharged him. Yes they said. Surely not in this state I thought.  
He began to recover but found that part of his memory had gone. After finally having Mri and Ct scans they were lesions that were found in his brain. To cut a long story short he has had another stroke this time I took him to Barnsley hospital. They were on the ball from the start. He has lost feeling all down one side and his eyesight has gone. He is now suppose to be in Rehab Kendray refused to take him because his doctors are in Wath. But we live under Barnsley council! Ridiculous red tape. He has now been transferred back to Rotherham and is back on the stroke ward... Worried is an understatement after seeing first hand how my partner was treated as an elderly stroke survivor! I witnessed other people not being helped to eat or drink even though they couldn't do it themselves. I am so worried he will not make a recovery if things haven't changed! Feeling sick to my stomach and have no confidence in Rotherham Hospital whatsoever.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
South West Yorkshire Partnership NHS Foundation Trust

author: muscapm68
title: Covid Vaccine at allergy clinic
body:
I was unable to book at South Lake centre due to not being suitable for Pfizer vaccine. The staff at the local call centre went above and beyond to get me an appointment at Craigavon Area Hospital. The nurse Olivia who phoned me was so caring and professional and had such a friendly voice that she immediately put me at ease. When I went for my vaccine I had the privilege of meeting Olivia and I can’t compliment her enough.
The whole team was excellent. The nurse who injected me was very professional and caring too and very reassuring. I’d previously had severe anaphylaxis so was a little apprehensive.
All in all my experience was brilliant and I look forward to attending for my second jab!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: LCon
title: My road to diagnosis
body:
After a referral in January 2020 by my gp, to be seen at gynae clinic due to an abnormal bleed, I was seen in Feb 2020 by Dr Gatongi, a further appointment made for May 2020 to be seen by Dr Monaghan, unfortunately I was too ill to attend.  
I was emergency admitted later in May and admitted to Gynae ward, then onto ward 54 at Victoria Kirkcaldy. All staff working between 23rd to 29th May that were assigned to my care were amazing staff who supported me through a very difficult time for me. I was confirmed with Kidney Cancer on the 26th May with a follow up ct scan to ensure no upper torso cancers. Mr Chapman gave me thus diagnosis and explained all follow up care to come. I discussed the possibility of being diagnosed with Lynch Syndrome as this was a possibility given my maternal family medical conditions.  
I was impressed with the advice and ongoing support put in place to support me with my diagnosis of Kidney Cancer, during a Covid Pandemic and difficult time for all Staff within the Victoria Hospital and I'm so thankful for their care and support during this surreal time.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Millington
title: About my uncle
body:
My uncle went into Daisyhill on Sunday. later that evening I phoned and asked the nurse about him and could I speak to him. They gave them the phone and I asked how he felt and he said he was looking home and started to cry. I was in a awful state. So he got moved up to ward on Monday.  
On Tuesday I tried phoning from 10 that morning till 6 could not get through, I know that they have been extremely busy. By this time I was really getting upset because you know at this time we cannot visit. So I phoned the virtual line and it was a God send. They had me talking face to face with my uncle and was able to content myself that he was ok.  
They have me booked in for the next 2 evenings. It was so straight forward everything went to a T and images where so clear and the girl was so helpful. Would definitely recommend this service to anyone who has a family member in hospital. Thankyou x

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kazzyd
title: It is so important to me
body: At this time I cannot get into the hospital to see my daddy so personally I do feel this way is much better than not being able to see or talk to my daddy at all, the girls on the phones while booking are amazing and have compassion which is so important to me so thank you so much for this.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Grainne
title: Pleasant, respectful and helpful care
body: Everyone - the receptionist, nursing assistant, radiographer and doctor were both   pleasant, respectful and helpful, and extremely   efficient. Within 30 minutes of arriving, I had been triaged, had an ECG, had blood taken, spoken with the he doctor and had an X-ray. The only significant waiting period wait was for the results of my blood test to come back. I particularly appreciated that everyone I interacted with took time to explain what they were doing and answer my questions.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Amcd
title: Bitten on the nose
body:
My 19 year old daughter was bitten by the family pet on her nose. As you can imagine we were very upset. I rang triage and the call handler was lovely and reassuring. A nurse rang me back quite quickly and again was lovely and reassuring. As advised we attended the emergency department and all staff from porters, to reception, nursing and medical staff were very kind, professional and helpful. As per current policy I couldn’t accompany my daughter into the treatment area but dr Ciaran reassured me that they would look after my daughter and kindly kept me updated of her care.  
My daughter felt reassured and looked after and they did an excellent job of suturing her nose.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: thomasr99
title: COVID-19 Vaccine
body:
Today I received my first dose of the COVID-19 Vaccine (Pfizer Biontech) at the Royal Victoria Hospital. My experience is as pleasant and friendly as it could possibly be, all staff were clearly on the ball and things ran smoothly. All the procedures in place were followed to the highest standard- every chair was sanitised after each person, social distancing was maintained throughout, and instructions from staff were clear.  
Looking forward to my second appointment.  
Thank you to all the health workers that have sacrificed and knuckled down throughout the duration of this pandemic. I hope it does not go unnoticed!

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: DavieNich
title: Hairmyres CCU excellent care
body: I was taken to Hairmyres with suspected heart attack, the speed and following care from start to finish was superb, from the ambulance crew, Doctors and Nurses right through until I was released, everybody was friendly and caring, thank you

author: marsxj38
title: My exceptional care
body:
On 20th Dec 2020, I was taken to Hairmyers with Covid 19. I was under the care of the HDU dept for 2 weeks where I was unaware of much due to sedation but I was aware that I was being cared for well.. I was then transferred to ICU and intubated for a week. My wife and family were kept up to date at all times by the excellent Doctors and nurses on both units and I was able to listen to them on the telephone. I particularly remember Margaret and Cheryl as 2 of the many nurses caring for me. After one week an attempt to extubate me was unsuccessful which led to a further week ventilated.  
I was eventually transferred to a Covid ward where the very hard working nurses were always on hand to assist. From there it was on to a general ward to be looked after by Collete , Susan, and Ellen and then ward 18b for rehabilitation. Nursing staff I remember included Melanie and Robyn.  
Many thanks also to the Physiotherapists Gavin, John, Vicki and to Kim for patience and understanding.  
The care provided by Hairmyers from December to my release in February was outstanding and I thank you on behalf of my family and myself. There are staff I have missed and every one of them provides exceptional care.  
Thanks

author: bravogr54
title: Thank you for the good work
body: I want to say thank you to Andrea, for their good work he is doing as he is young and passionate about his work. thank you.

author: Crohn’s Patient
title: Excellent IBD team at RAH, Paisley
body:
Following a telephone consultation with my consultant today, I thought I’d like to share my experience of the IBD team at the RAH in Paisley. For over 20 years, I have attended the RAH in Paisley for Crohn’s Disease. During that time, I have seen an improvement in the service provided to patients since the set up of the IBD Helpline.  
Via the helpline, the brilliant Alan, Seth and Fiona provide invaluable advice re medication and the management of symptoms but, equally important, they provide reassurance when my Crohn’s is bad and I feel at my lowest ebb. The communication and co-ordination between the IBD nurses and my consultant, Dr Naismith, is excellent. I’m sure many people have experienced doctors with a paternal attitude who simply dictate what our treatment should be but Dr Naismith always listens to my opinions and concerns and discusses my options. He takes time to explain new treatments and is always honest about the likelihood of success of such treatments. Dr Naismith’s secretary, Karen, should also get a mention for being lovely, helpful and professional.I can’t thank Dr Naismith’s IBD team enough for the care I’ve had over the years, nor can I over emphasise the importance of having access to such a team.

author: Blakey66
title: NHS Borders ( BGH )
body:
I was admitted to the Borders General Hospital with a suspected minor stroke & ongoing cardio problems.  
I could not of wished to be looked after by a better team. All the ward staff were incredibly nice people, the nurses were wonderfully kind & attentive. The doctors & specialists were very business like but not overbearing & rude like others I have dealt with in the past.  
The care received was excellent, even more so under the current world pandemic. An excellent team.  
The food was top notch as well.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Elikk45
title: Covid 19 vaccine
body: Very impressed with the system and vaccine delivery at the covid vaccination centre in Belfast. Very smooth and efficient.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Dinosaur
title: Urgent care hand over to A/E
body: Because urgent care handed me over to A/E clerk and I then got forgotten and sat for over 3 hours in A/E waiting for blood tests and an ENT bed. I felt very unwell as I had a high fever and could not swallow and could not talk and managed to catch member of staffs attention who found out that A/E had not booked me after after the urgent care Doctor gave them my form. I was then quickly put onto a trolley and given pain relief and cannula in very quickly before going up to ward of which ENT were waiting for me.

author: DavieNich
title: Trying to get a sick line from my GP
body:
Trying to get a sick line from my GP after having heart stent  
I feel things could be made easier at a time when I am supposed to be stress free, my GP says I need to get a sick line from the hospital ( who will only give a sick line for the time in hospital ). My work needs a line for any and all time I am not fit for work, So why can't my own Gp do this service and how do I get this issue fixed.

author: WJB
title: Heart failure and kidney problems
body:
Recently returned from Cyprus where I had a stent fitted. On return I registered with the Bingham surgery who assigned me a cardiac nurse to monitor my condition. They not only monitored my heart but found I had kidney problems. After regular blood tests and adjustment to my medication all now is back to a manageable level. I consider the treatment that I have received by the cardiac team second to none.
Very many thanks to you all for what I consider a fantastic service.

author: ophiuchuswq45
title: Vaccination
body:
Very professional and caring services. Great staff with expert knowledge.
Thanks

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Bill D
title: First class care
body: Came in, got taken early. Was fully informed of procedure - embolization - fitted expertly with cannula and walked down to theatre. Expertly and warmly treated and supported throughout. Good humour and first class care. Thanks very much to both doctors who carried out procedure - recovering nicely no complications. Special thanks to Catherine in theatre for encouragement and support and to Allison and Bobby and Cerys and Michelle and the nurse who made a brilliant cup of tea and an egg sandwich.

author: Hamward1
title: Covid and my care
body:
‘We recently had an outbreak of Coronavirus on our ward (Hambleton), I was really scared, I worry when I have a slightly cold, so when I was confirmed as having Corona virus it was really scary, but I cannot fault that staff one bit, I have never felt more cared for in my life. If I needed a cup of tea during the night because I couldn’t sleep or was anxious they would bring it to me and reassure me. They went above and beyond for the patients on this ward, I cant thank them enough’.
Thanks

author: octoberbh68
title: Birth of our baby boy
body:
I gave birth to our son in Jan 2021 via emergency c section at the Queen Elizabeth maternity hospital in Glasgow and I just wanted to give feedback on our experience. We are so unbelievably grateful to all the maternity staff for the amazing level of care we received during the 4 days I was in hospital. I had an induction on the Sunday and my waters were broken on the Tuesday night. After an extremely long, painful and traumatic 15 hours of labour, I had to have an emergency c section to deliver my son. The level of care I received from the Sunday right through to when we left the hospital on the Thursday evening was phenomenal. It was a very traumatic time for me and my partner and my son and the maternity staff took the best care of us and were with us supporting us the entire time. The maternity staff do amazing jobs, let alone during a pandemic, which you would not have known was going on outside as the level of care, professionalism and attention each and every midwife gave us was second to none. I want to say the most special thanks to Ann the staff midwife who was with us during the 15 hour labour, c section and after care for me, my partner and my son. With Ann was midwife Diane who was on placement from Shetlands, they took the best care of us and we genuinely could not have done it without them. To Katie, our doctor who safely delivered our son, again you are such a special person and did a wonderful job. To the anesthetists who were with us during the c section, John and Fintan, your support in keeping me calm and taking fantastic care of me the whole time, thank you thank you thank you!! . You are all truly wonderful people and are amazing at what you do, you are very very special people who we will never forget.  
Thank you so so very much

author: Patient1957
title: Vaccination
body: Both my wife and myself are in our 60s with underlying health conditions but still await vaccination I personally know of others in other health boards who are in their 50s with no health conditions who have already been vaccinated.

author: lm1990
title: TMJ Surgery
body:
I was admitted to Ward 62 at the institute of neurological sciences on 3/3/2021 for TMJ disc repositioning under the care of Mr Halsnad.  
I would just like to express my thanks to Mr Halsnad and his team, he kept me well informed and comfortable throughout, explaining the procedure thoroughly and detailing what had been done following on from the procedure. The team on Ward 62 (domestics, HCSWs, Student Nurses & Staff Nurses) are amazing, from the moment I was admitted through to my discharge the next day they couldn’t have done enough. Three in particular, Ben, Ellie (student) & Jennifer are an absolute credit to the ward. My thanks also to the theatre/recovery team who looked after me, only wish I had caught the name of the theatre nurse who held my hand just as I was going under and the recovery nurse who done everything to make sure I was comfortable when I came round - thank you!! Thank you once again Mr Halsnad & Team.

author: ECH1
title: Covid vaccination
body:
Well organised.
Good support network of volunteers and professional nurses.
Well explained and good care given.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Negan95
title: Maternity Physio Appointment
body:
Massive thank you to the lovely ladies in the physio department at Wishaw General yesterday. ( I believe it was Rachel & Kirsty)  
I am currently 29 weeks with baby number 2 and was really struggling with lower back/bum leg pain.  
I have never been to physio before so wasn’t entirely sure what to expect.  
They were incredible, a complete credit to the NHS!  
I felt so comfortable and they listened, gave me so much support and guidance going forward and for after baby. I learned exactly what was wrong and why and honestly couldn’t thank them enough.

author: sambazm83
title: Covid injection
body: Very well looked after, everything explained well. Very efficient.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Ang5
title: Scottish ambulance
body: Had to phone for an emergency ambulance for my dad who was unwell. First responder Ryan turned up and provided excellent and professional care. Ryan was very knowledgeable in the care he was providing. He was so calm and made the situation so much better when he arrived. The paramedic and technician then arrived a while later who were Frances and Chris and the care and attention they gave my dad was excellent. Again very knowledgeable and so professional. Thanks to all involved who made a very emotional and scary situation better for all.

author: Lp40
title: Recent inpatient experience ward 210
body: I had a recent stay in ward 210 following a hysterectomy.   All anxieties were relieved meeting the medical and nursing team on the ward including student nurses who really did show compassion and nothing was too much trouble particularly Leah!   The staff on the ward were excellent, easy to talk to and very helpful, as were the medical staff who took time to reassure and give explanations in layman's terms which is always helpful.   Couldn't fault the care I received thanks again!

author: swingpy88
title: day surgery
body:
I was recently admitted to day surgery at Queen Margaret Hospital in Dunfermline for a small procedure where I needed to be put to sleep. I was very nervous and anxious before coming in but I would just like to say I received 1st class treatment from the moment I arrived on the ward to the moment I left. I don't actually think I could have received any better care if I had went private. All the staff on the ward were so nice and couldn't do enough to help me, and as for the tea and toast it was even better than fish and chips.  
During my stay we had a wee bit of excitement as the fire alarm went off and we all had to evacuate the ward even though it was a false alarm, this was done so quickly and efficiently that I knew I would be in great hands (you could tell they have done this before!) even sitting out in the corridor the nursing staff were all talking and joking with us.  
I would like to thank all the staff especially Nola, Mandy and Nikki as they just made my day. Thank you

author: Liam88
title: Vaccine centre
body: Went to South Lakes for my first vaccine, very well organised and very safe. Big thanks and appreciation to those people working there!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: empathyzy86
title: Vaccination
body: Great experience. Felt very informed and supported throughout process. Staff very competent and helpful.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: JCO
title: Video call with my grandmother in the trauma ward
body:
Last night was the first night I used the virtual call and the call went really well. But tonight I got disconnected for some reason. The signal might have went. But thankfully I was able to ring her and explain. Tonight she is in a private room whereas last night she was on the open ward so maybe that was the issue. It did freeze once as well. I have noticed though if I happen to talk or laugh at the same time as her speaking it cancels her out and then I can't hear her.  
Other than that it is a brilliant idea and I'm glad that the service is available during these times as it is so hard not seeing her in person. But it keeps me content seeing and knowing she is ok and getting a good chat face to face on screen. Thank you for this service. Much appreciated. I understand that technology has it glitches, so it has not deterred me from continuing to use this service. Thanks again.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: User GG
title: Hospital stay
body:
Admitted to hospital with appendix pain.  
The staff and service were good, But they could do with more staff.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: scoreboardhd89
title: Virtual visit at Craigavon is fantastic
body:
My father has been in Craigavon for over a week now. We have used the Virtual Visit a number of times. It is fantastic. You can speak and see him. When you can't visit due to COVID this is an excellent way to see your loved one and for them to see you.  
It makes the 'visit' a bit more personal.  
The staff are amazing, friendly, efficient and caring. Today the call my Mother was to have needed to be changed and the member of staff did not want to leave her a voicemail so she contacted another family member to rearrange. She wanted to make sure the visit went ahead as it means so much to both of them.  
For family who are not able to travel this would be an excellent service to develop even when we return to being able to visit.  
Well done Southern Health and Social Care for this service.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: J71
title: Kate - Barrington Ward receptionist
body: My mum got admitted in the night to Barrington Ward so first thing I called the ward to see how she was. As handover was happening I said I would call back. When I did I was greated by a lovely friendly voice, Kate. She explained no news on my mum as waiting for the consultant to do his rounds. She said she would call me when he was doing the ward round. She did as she said. And I was going to call when the round was complete but to my lovely surprise the consultant called me. I felt so thought of and was so well informed and helped. Thank you Kate and all on Barrington Ward.

author: Jen74
title: Diabetes care
body: The community team have supported me and guided me every step of the way, they are always just a phone call away if I have any concerns or issues.   They were a great help and support when I had to progress onto insulin, they alleviated my fears and gave me all the advice and support I could ask for.   A fantastic team very friendly and approachable well done to them all

author: octansqw66
title: feel welcomed by staff 100%
body: Coming into this unit I was made to feel welcomed by staff 100%. Very helpful, very understanding. staff made sure to pass on messages from my family phoning and nothing seemed to much trouble. the unit was spotless.

author: CraigC
title: Absolutely awesome
body: The Gastro Team at the Victoria hospital Kirkcaldy reply on their phone service very fast. I think there absolutely awesome, they really look after you!

author: equuleusqh48
title: My care after a stroke
body:
I was brought to Crosshouse Hospital by ambulance. The crew were brilliant and very knowledgeable.  
Ward 322 was where I was admitted and the staff were absolutely brilliant as well. I was treated very well and cared for with the highest regard. My treatment was very successful and I was discharged on day 3.  
The staff were really good and supported me with my recovery.

author: Dunfiebroon
title: Type 2 Diabetes
body: Referred by my GP to NHS Fife Community Diabetic Team who have been tremendous in assisting me understand the effects of my insulin and tablets and have lead to better control of my blood sugars especially at work.

author: hippozb93
title: The passing of my darling Husband
body:
My husband passed away in September 2020 at the age of 67 although he had diabetes, end stage kidney disease, and a number of other medical problems he didn’t pass away with any of his on going illnesses we had been married for 41 years and I had known him for 50 years so I feel so empty without him my heart really feels broken, but speaking to a bereavement practitioner on a weekly basis I feel helped me to speak to someone outside my family I was able to tell them things I could not discuss with my daughters in fear I would upset them.  
I was In a really dark place and I do still feel really down but with the help of this bereavement practitioner's chats she has helped me a through this very dark time in my life I cannot thank her enough for her kind words and for her patience for just listening.

author: Hopye76
title: So happy and grateful for my vaccination
body:
I would like to thank all the volunteers and staff at Foyle Arena vaccination centre (Northern Ireland) for their efficiency, professionalism and good humour.  
I received my first vaccination there this morning and I am so happy and grateful to everyone who works there. The whole process (including the 15 minutes recuperation period) was over in under 35 minutes. Fantastic!

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: rainey68
title: No words can describe the care
body:
I used the services of the stroke ward at Crosshouse Hospital for over 12 days.  
No words could describe the care and compassion I received from staff. To watch this well-oiled machine day to day filled me with pride in our NHS and I will always hold a button for the selfless individuals, from the cleaners to the auxiliary, nurses, ward nurses, students and doctors, thank you!

author: lotionhk74
title: Admission to day ward Larbert Hospital Forth Valley
body: I want to tell you my story and experience from start to finish. I was admitted to the hospital for surgery and stayed overnight. It’s a frightening thing going into hospital and under a general Anaesthetic. I was under Mr Mcllhenny who was fantastic. When I went for my ore-op appointment with him he said my operation would be at the end of February. True to his word I went in on the 3rd of March only a few days Later. From admission to discharge I can only say my experience was amazing. I would like to say a big thank you to all the staff in a Larbert involved in my care from the Consultant/Surgeon, nurses, doctors, staff who prepped me in the side room before theatre, theatre staff, my surgeon, the staff in recovery to all the staff in the day ward of Forth Valley Hospital in Larbert who looked after me. I was in on 3rd March to 4th of March. I think you are all wonderful and I’ve never met such wonderful professional bunch of people. I was pretty nervous but they made me feel welcome. I also felt extremely safe in all of their hands. They looked after me so well I can’t thank everyone enough. 💯 % was given by every member of staff including the staff who cleaned my room to the staff who brought my food thank you all so much I mean this from the bottom of my heart. It’s not often you meet a team of people who are all so great that’s the reason no individual names are mentioned here because there would be to many to mention with all the shift changes I saw. You are all fantastic. I can’t forget the nurse who showed me the way into the ward when I was lost. It was the very same nurse who carried my bag downstairs to meet my husband on my discharge he was Irish. I feel quite emotional as I’m writing this because without all of you where would we all be. You all do a fantastic job in extremely difficult times and I just wanted to say to all of you from the bottom of my heart ❤️ To Mr Mcllhenny and his team thank you all so much for looking after me with such professionalism and care.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: caring and patient even with covid pressures
body:
needed a referral to an allergist for new food allergy development and dr was very thorough and patient listening to my concerns. also needed an emergency medicine refill and he got it done quickly without it being a problem or rushing through the appt.

only issue is as a hard of hearing patient is sometimes difficult for me to communicate exclusively over the phone and so i have my spouse listen in to help explain anything i may not have heard or heard wrong. dr wanted to speak to either me or spouse so i had to do the call myself without spouse to interpret. the audio quality made it difficult to hear what he said and so i had to ask him to repeat a lot.

title: Brilliant people
body: Just spent a week there on ward 2B after a PE. All staff absolutely brilliant, really friendly and helpful and I just want to say a big massive thank you

readBy.name: St Helens and Knowsley Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Excellent treatment in every way
body: My appointment was with a urology consultant but my traetment was perfect at every stage from reception, nurses station to consultant I was treated with exceptional care and respect, and felt that people were actually listening to me which is unusual nowadays. Great care was taken to explain every stage and I was given the opportunity to ask questions . Please pass on my congratulations and grateful thanks to all those involved.

author: Marshmallow53
title: Great experience
body: Great experience receiving COVID vaccine at RVH Belfast on Friday. All staff encountered were so helpful and knowledgeable and determined to put us all at ease - genuinely a great experience!

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: mayms89
title: COVID - Staff smoking
body:
Whilst outside wishaw general this morning unable to visit my sick husband due to COVID rules, I was deeply concerned to witness a number of your staff outside in uniform smoking, no masks no social distancing! If your own staff can't adhere to the regulations and are blatantly at the front of the hospital smoking and breaking the rules, how then can we have any confidence of the staff inside!  
This is shameful NHS Lanarkshire!

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Jen74
title: Help and support from the community diabetes team
body:
The community team have supported me and guided me every step of the way, they are always just a phone call away if I have any concerns or issues.  
They were a great help and support when I had to progress on to insulin, they alleviated my fears and gave me all the advice and support I could ask for.  
A fantastic team very friendly and approachable well done to them all.

author: Marzz73
title: Covid Vaccination
body: Just a quick note to say how impressed I was with the Covid Vaccination centre in the RVH. Staff were really lovely and welcoming and were so efficient. Great service

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: centaurusqs73
title: First class care, with a smile
body:
Everything about Crosshouse Hospital has been first class. I know the moment I arrived the staff couldn't do enough for me and others.  
The meals are 5 star and I've enjoyed all of them. As for the ward, I couldn't be better cared for and always with a smile.

title: Amazing practice
body:
This is my practice and always looked after well.  The staff are brilliant and very considerate. Whether you call, visit online or in person I am always satisfied the service and care I receive.  I also had my jab in late Jan for my medical condition and everything was run smoothly. From the moment I entered the small queue by the door and my exit everything was planned and executed well.  
Well done team ECHWC.

author: serpenssw96
title: The support I got
body: After a lengthy admission process from evening over night until a bed came available at 7. 30am, it was a relief to be cared for in the ward thereafter. Despite being confronted with so many different faces and not remembering names everyone has been so attentive and helpful as I settled and was able to move about taking me to wherever I needed to go and supported me as I got stronger.

title: Lack of knowledge and broken promises
body: I have recently contacted my GP Dalston Practice as I had read that the priority group I was assigned to for my covid vaccine had all been invited for their shot.  I however had not been invited and so called the practice as advised.  The practice phone lines are supposed to be open from 8am.  They never are.  On finally reaching someone on reception I informed them of the issue and was surprised that they did not know my underlying health condition was part of this category.  I was promised a call back.  This never happened.  I called the next day.  Same issues.  Promised a call back in the afternoon.  This never happened.  I called that evening and was assured I would receive communication in the next 2 days.  Still waiting.  It would appear that I have to beg(multiple times) for a vaccine that I am, according to the government, already supposed to have been offered?
